0:
```json
{
  "Model_Purpose": {
    "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model. The model is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption. The study aims to examine the role that networked elites have in diffusing a non-punishment-enforced norm through an artificial society.",
    "research_questions": [
      "How do humanitarian norms that lack associated punishments for non-compliance diffuse across society?",
      "What is the role of elites in the diffusion of social norms of humanitarianism?"
    ],
    "system_boundaries": [],
    "outcome_variables": {
      "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers)",
      "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values",
      "peer_weight_e": "Weight placed on interactions with other elite agents",
      "network_size": "Randomized size of network of ‘followers’ of elites",
      "advocate_weight_g": "Weight the advocate exerts on general agents",
      "elite_weight": "Weight given to a networked elite’s norm adoption",
      "general_weight": "Weight given to a one-on-one interaction with a general agent",
      "peer_weight_g": "Weight given to average humanitarian values of a group of nearby agents",
      "percent_advocates": "Percentage of agent population who are advocates who promote a norm",
      "advocate_zeal": "Homogeneous value given to advocate agents’ humanitarianism values",
      "degrade_percent": "Amount per time step that an agent degrades its humanitarianism values, to represent donor/compassion fatigue",
      "mu_activist_state": "Mean humanitarianism value of all general agents (heterogeneous)",
      "mu_activist_threshold": "Mean threshold value of all general agents beyond which they become active humanitarian actors"
    }
  }
}
```
1:
```json
{
    "Model_Purpose": {
        "full_description": "The purpose of this model is to understand the impact of elites in the spread of norms as an extension of a previous model (Salimi et al. 2018). This model is not yet at a stage where we are prepared to verify and validate the model, so we instead performed diagnostics on the model using the ANTS algorithms to look for anomalies across the parameter space. The diagnostics did not indicate problems with the current prototype model that produce erratic results or unexplained outcomes. Future iterations of the model will look to more robust methods of verification and validation. The current model, founded predominantly on norm diffusion theory, is designed to test assumptions of norm diffusion theories in an environment where peer pressure is the only mechanism for punishment-based enforcement of norm adoption.",
        "research_questions": [
            "How do elites influence the diffusion of norms in an artificial society?",
            "What is the role of peer pressure in the adoption of humanitarian norms?",
            "How can norm diffusion occur without punishment-based enforcement?"
        ],
        "system_boundaries": [
            "The model includes three types of agents: elites, advocates, and general population.",
            "The environment is designed to simulate norm diffusion based on peer pressure."
        ],
        "outcome_variables": {
            "percent_elites": "Percentage of population who are elites (influencers).",
            "advocate_weight_e": "Weight advocate exerts on the elite agent’s humanitarianism values.",
            "peer_weight_e": "Weight placed on interactions with other elite agents.",
            "network_size": "Randomized size of network of ‘followers’ of elites.",
            "advocate_weight_g": "Weight the advocate exerts on general agents.",
            "elite_weight": "Weight given to a networked elite’s norm adoption.",
            "general_weight": "Weight given to a one-on-one interaction with a general agent.",
            "peer_weight_g": "Weight given to average humanitarian values of a group of nearby agents.",
            "percent_advocates": "Percentage of agent population who are advocates who promote a norm.",
            "advocate_zeal": "Homogeneous value given to advocate agents’ humanitarianism values.",
            "degrade_percent": "Amount per time step that an agent degrades its humanitarianism values, to represent donor/compassion fatigue.",
            "mu_activist_state": "Mean humanitarianism value of all general agents (heterogeneous).",
            "mu_activist_threshold": "Mean threshold value of all general agents beyond which they become active humanitarian actors (heterogeneous).",
            "Population": "Total population of agents."
        }
    }
}
```

            "The model includes three types of agents: elites, advocates, and the general population.",

        }

}
